Author_affil: Institute of International Forestry and Forest Products, Technische UniversitÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¤t Dresden

Stated_int: NTFP commercialization
Desired_out: Gum arabic, frankincense, myrrh, and oppopanex are economically viable commercial NTFPs and represent important sources of livelihoods of local community, employment, & foreign exchange earnings. Stated_outcomes: Contribution of gum & resin income to household economy, level of engagement & experience with gum/resin production, absolute & relative gum & resin income across income quartiles, expenditure of income from gum & resin, seasonality of income, role of income in poverty mitigation and reducing income inequality, determinants of income
Portion_livelihood_amount: Gum and resin production and collection represent an integral part of householdsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ livelihood sources in the study areas. These NTFPs generate considerable cash income contributing to 21%, 14%, 20% and 23% of the total household income in Ummrawaba, Elnehud, Abergelle and Borena, respectively (Figure 2). The income variation basically corresponds to the gradient of the resource management, increasing from open-access wild resource (in Borena) to regulated access natural woodland (Abergelle) and to intensively managed gum gardens on private lands (Ummrawaba and Elnehud).
Study_goal: The study was motivated by the following research questions: (i) To what extent does the economic gain derived from the small-scale production of natural gum and resins impact rural livelihood improvement and poverty alleviation? (ii) What factors explain the inter-household and regional (inter-case) variations in the level of income and dependence on gum and resin incomes? (iii) What lessons and recommendations can be drawn to promote rural economic development based on commercialization of high value NTFPs in the dryland regions of Ethiopia and Sudan?

community forest (CF) resource management in Nepal have increased
access of poorer households to the resources.The working hypotheses of the paper are: (1) the poor are, in absolute terms, less dependent, but, in relative terms, more dependent than the â€˜less poorâ€™ on forest resources; (2) there are differential impacts of CF management and the poor benefits less than the rich or â€˜less poorâ€™; and (3) ability to use the CF resources is directly linked to heterogeneity in private resource endowments of
households.

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL AND EXCHANGE ENTITLEMENTS FROM EUCALYPTUS WOODLOTS: THE CASE OF MUKONO DISTRICT IN UGANDA
Author_affil: Makerere University, Faculty of Forestry and Nature Conservation, P.O. Box 7062, Kampala, Uganda
Funding: Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad)
Stated_int: Cultivation of Eucalyptus through taungya techniques
Desired_out: Taungya is a form of land rent in kind where the taungya farmers don't directly pay the tree farmers but provide free labour for certain tasks such as clearing the land, weeding and biomass waste management to tree farmers who in tum allow them to grow their crops under trees. Under taungya arrangement, there is normally no written agreement between the tree farmer and taungya practitioner. The latter party according to the unwritten agreement must clear or prepare the land and grow annual crops. Taungya farmers must weed trees and are not allowed to kill, destroy or vandalise any young plant or undertake any tree tending operations.'
Stated_outcomes: Employment from taungya practices, collection of firewood
Study_goal: How and when do different resource claimants gain access to the benefits from woodlots? How are these entitlements appropriated?'
Study_location: Mukono district

Stated_mech: Environmental entitlements framework (Leach et al. 1999)

Our aim is not to carry out a statistical inference but to perform a comparative income measurement analysis of two cork oak forest with the advantage that there is detailed microeconomic data that enables us to make an in-depth analysis of the natural resource conservation and total commercial income measure- ment from the perspectives of Spain's developed economy and Tunisia's developing economy'

Title: Decentralization, market integration and efficiency-equity trade-offs: Evidence from Joint Forest Management in Ethiopian villages
Author_affil: School of Economics, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, Cape Town 7701, South Africa
Funding: Volkswagen Foundation and University of Johannesburg, Economic Research Southern Africa, EfD (EDRI/EEPFE) SIDA
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management, community forest enterprises, marketing of NTFPs
Desired_out: The general objectives of these programs are to arrest deforestation and forest degradation while improving the welfare of those who are heavily dependent on the forest for their livelihoods. In essence, the programs are intended to achieve these twin goals by incentivizing local communities to manage state forests. However, there are pervasive imperfections in forest products markets that constrain the needed incentives; these imperfections arise mainly from limited infrastructure, high transport costs, few buyers, exploitive marketing chains and imperfect price information. One innovative approach to overcome these problems, which has been adopted by the Ethiopian government, is to organize JFM into community forest enterprises (CFE) in the form of forest usersâ€™ cooperatives (FUC) for forest products marketing.4 This provides the community with avenues for greater participation in value chains of forest products markets through vertical integration (VI) (Antinori, 2005; Gelo and Koch, 2014; Vega and Keenan, 2014). Vertical integration is expected to raise NTFP prices and hence spurs the required incentives by shortening the marketing chain and increasing bargaining power of farmers along NTFP market value chain.'
Stated_outcomes: Changes in household welfare
Study_goal: It is aimed at evaluating the income and distributive effects of a JFM program augmented by market linkage interventions.'
Study_location: Gimbo District

Stated_int: REDD+, Meru Betiri National Park
Desired_out: The stated objective is to contribute to tropical forest conservation by enhancing community participation in conservation activities and sustainable park management. The project aims to achieve the following objectives: (1) to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding the park and (2) to develop a credible measuring, reporting, and verifying (MRV) system for monitoring the reduction of emissions caused by deforestation and forest degradation and for enhancing forest carbon stocks in MBNP. The specific outputs from activities are: (1) improved participation of the local community in forest management; (2) developing alternative sources of income to improve the livelihoods of local communities living inside and in the area surrounding MBNP; (3) reduction and reporting of illegal logging and forest encroachment; (4) improving the capacity to conduct an inventory of the resource base and carbon accounting in a measurable, reportable, and verifiable form; (5) preparing a report on comprehensive baseline data and an estimation of the emissions reduction and carbon stock enhancement of the national park; and (6) establishing and validating a system for monitoring emissions reductions and the enhancement of carbon stocks.'
Stated_outcomes: Difference in income between participants vs. non-participants
Study_goal: This study investigates whether REDD+ projects could generate sufficient economic incentives and social motivations for local people through participating in protecting forests, and draws implications for developing a national REDD+ strategy suitable for circumstances in the field. The research objectives have been: (1) to assess how the relationships between local people and national park authorities have been established through the REDD+ project; (2) to identify the positive social and economic impacts of the REDD+ project on local people; (3) to make clear local awareness of the national park and REDD+ project; and (4) to make clear motivations for participating in the REDD+ project. '
Study_location: Curahnongko, Sanenrejo villages inside and outside Meru Betiri National Park, Jawa Timur

Desired_out: Partnership between county government and private company involved in bamboo shoot processing and marketing, and is part of a province and nationwide voluntary rural resettlement program associated with the nationâ€™s wider rural poverty alleviation strategy.' Migrants relocated from areas of high poverty, low opportunity to area to grow bamboo as cash crops. Plantation with housing and amenities built, along with infrastructure. 'Migrants entered into a contractual relationship with both the county government (for the land) and the company (for the bamboo shoots), whereby the migrants were allowed to use their land only for growing bamboo and were under contract to sell their bamboo shoots exclusively to the company (the end market for the shoots was mostly Japan or Taiwan).'

Title: Forest restoration to achieve both ecological and economic progress, Poyang Lake basin, China
Author_affil: The Institute of Geographical Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 100101 Beijing, China
Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (40971281, 41001366) and the Ministry of Science and Technology 973 Program (2009CB421105)
Stated_int: Mountain-River-Lake Program, forest restoration, lake and river restoration, poverty alleviation
Desired_out: The Mountain-River-Lake Program (MRL) was launched in Chinaâ€™s Poyang Lake basin in 1983, and focused on eco-restoration and poverty reduction.'...'The MRL program provides access to technology, financial resources and information to farmers who directly manage the ecosystems. Since 1997, participatory methods were introduced that involve farmers in the entire process of problem analysing, project planning, decision making, implementing, monitoring and evaluating, and follow-up management.' 'To move farmers away from a form of forestry that was focused on harvesting wood for fuel, the government encouraged the con- struction of infrastructure to provide methane generation facilities for every household. 'The government encouraged the transfer of land ownership to residents who were willing to plant trees and prohibit tree felling'
Stated_outcomes: Ecological effectiveness (forest cover, carbon sequestration, soil and water conservation), change in net income, ratio of net income to net consumption expenditure, change in number of persons below poverty line
Study_goal: To assess the efficacy of such a huge program, when the whole community was involved in pursuing a well-articulated environ- mental restoration and poverty reduction strategy, we evaluated the programâ€™s impacts by rigorous before and after comparisons in Poyang Lake basin, and identify the potential links between environmental policy and sustainability development'
Study_location: Poyang Lake basin (181 representative villages)

Title:
Has Forest Co-management in Malawi
Benefited the Poor?
Journal: Book: Political Institutions and Development: Failed Expectations and Renewed Hopes
Stated_int:
Devolution of forest rights and management: Forest co-management in Malawi. 1996 National Forestry Policy & National Forestry Program. Specifically, In 1996 the World Bank and the British government, through the Department
for International Development initiated a pilot forest co-management
program in Malawi.
Desired_out: Sustainable management, improved livelihoods: The program was designed to promote local participation in forest management in exchange for the benefits of long-term sustainable management, such as continued access to fuel wood, poles and non-timber forest products
Stated_outcomes: Impacts of participation in the forest co-management program on household income

Author_affil: Laboratory of Global Forest Environmental Studies, Department of Global Agricultural Sciences, Graduate School of Global Agriculture and Life Sciences, The University of Tokyo
Funding: University Grants Commission of Bangladesh
Stated_int: Participatory forest management
Desired_out: The projects studied were aimed at poor forest-dependent people in engaging in PF to improve their livelihoods and consequently to reduce the forest destruction.' 'The Forest Department in Coxâ€™s Bazar followed the interval of 2 m 9 2 m for planting trees in PF project areas. Each participant was allotted a 1- or 2-ha plantation under the PF program based on land availability. Rotation of the plantation was fixed as 10 years by the Forest Department. After the final harvest, each participant will receive 45 % of the total return of their allotted plantation. The Forest Department will receive 45 % of the final return as the cost of management of the plantation. And the remaining part of the return (i.e., 10 %) will be deposited in a tree farming fund (TFF) for the next term of plantations. But other returns such as fuel wood, litter, or products from intermediate tending operations were enjoyed solely by the participants'
Stated_outcomes: Income sources, human capital, physical capital, financial capital, natural capital, social capital

Title: Does â€˜â€˜Participationâ€™â€™ in Common Pool Resource Management Help the Poor? A Social Costâ€“Benefit Analysis of Joint Forest Management in Jharkhand, India
Author_affil: University of Cambridge, UK
Funding: Society for Promotion of Wastelands Development, New Delhi
Stated_int: Joint Forest Management (JFM), Village Forest Committee (VFC)
Desired_out:
In a follow-up document issued in 1990, Central government issued guidelines to all State governments to implement â€˜â€˜joint forest management systems in order to regenerate forests
and reduce rural poverty.... These guidelines suggested that the State governments may devolve everyday forest protection, management and development responsibilities to local community institutions (co-operative or committee-based) at the village or panchayat levels, 8 and prescribe benefit-sharing arrangements following regeneration'
Stated_outcomes: Change in costs and benefits to households from forests under JFM versus those not under JFM, Number of trees
Study_goal: The paper begins with a description of Indiaâ€™s forest problems and policies, and a more specific account of the assumptions about â€˜â€˜communityâ€™â€™ and â€˜â€˜rural povertyâ€™â€™ that inform the agendas of Joint Forest Management (Section 2). Section 3 describes the patterns of community stratification and forest use in the study area, and in Section 4 the assumptions that underpin the social costâ€“benefit model are reviewed. Section 5 presents the main findings. It concludes that nonpoor members of VFCs determine the social time preference of JFM. It also shows how the management regimes for JFM forests that are put into place by VFCs must discriminate against the poor, often to a debilitating extent. Section 6 highlights the need for a more comprehensive SCBA that would take into account the value of local ecological services from JFM forests.'
Study_location: Sarsa, Kelende, Bisa, Sadma, Banadag, Saheda, Tengariya, Bargainbanda villages - Ranchi District, Jharkhand State

Title:
Booming markets for Moroccan argan oil appear to
benefit some rural households while threatening
the endemic argan forest
Author_affil: Agricultural and Resource Economics, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Stated_int:
Moroccoâ€™s argan oil is now the most expensive edible oil in the
world. High-value argan markets have sparked a bonanza of argan
activity.
Desired_out:
Nongovernmental organizations, international and domestic
development agencies, and argan oil cooperatives aggressively
promote the winâ€“win aim of simultaneously benefiting local people
and the health of the argan forest.
Int_dur: Since 1999, rapidly appreciating prices in high-value markets have sparked a bonanza of argan activity.
Stated_outcomes:
Three types of household welfare outcomes: consumption
(spending at market), assets (livestock holdings), and childrenâ€™s
education
Study_goal:
Winâ€“win claims of poverty alleviation and biodiversity conservation
now appear on virtually every argan product label and
have been showcased by media outlets worldwide. Using a combination
of household- and landscape-level analyses, we evaluate
these now common argan claims.
Study_location: Essaouira Province
Study_duration: Survey conducted in 1999 and again in 2007
Stated_mech:
Forest products often function as an important safety net by helping vulnerable households cope with hard times and thereby, may prevent households
from slipping farther into poverty, but it may be difficult for such
households to leverage forest products as a means of accumulating
the assets needed to shift to higher-return pursuits.
Furthermore, even the safety net benefit can be compromised if
commercialization depletes forest resources, leaving vulnerable
households more susceptible to adverse shocks that can drive
them deeper into poverty.

Title: Improving the bene ts to the poor from community forestry in the Churia region of Nepal
Author_affil: CARE Nepal, Krishna Galli, Patan, P.O. Box 1661, Kathmandu, Nepal
Funding: Output from an action research project conducted by CARE Nepal with support of CARE International, CARE Austria, CARE Denmark, the Overseas Development Institute (ODI) and Ford Foundation.

Desired_out: Introduce programmes specially designed to increase the wellbeing of the poor, vulnerable and socially excluded people living in these areas'
Stated_outcomes: Financial capital, physical capital, human capital, natural capital, social capital, political capital
Study_goal:
The Nepal research was conducted in 2006-7 by CARE Nepal to understand and improve the livelihood impacts of community forestry in the Churia, Bhawar and Terai regions. The research was designed to answer several basic questions:
1. Can community forestry contribute to poverty reduction or livelihood improvement by providing rural people with a sustainable stream of net benefits greater than those obtained under a non-community forestry situation?
2. How significant are the benefits of community forestry for different wellbeing groups? What are the key negative impacts of community forestry and on whom do they fall?
3. What characteristics of community forestry determine its impacts (both positive and negative) on poverty and equity?'

Title:
THE ROLE OF PARTICIPATORY SOCIAL FORESTRY
IN THE ENHANCEMENT OF THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC
CONDITION OF THE RURAL POOR: A CASE STUDY OF
DHAKA FOREST DIVISION IN BANGLADESH
Author_affil: Forest Policy Laboratory, Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Shinshu University, 8304 Minamiminowa - mura, 399 - 4598 Nagano - ken, Japan.
Funding: The authors also acknowledge JSPS authority of Japan for sponsoring the research fund.
Stated_int: Social forestry program in Bangladesh
Desired_out:
Social forestry is an umbrella term broadly associated with practicing
forestry activities involving local people and other relevant stakeholders as active partner under a legal frame work of benefit sharing in order to improve the forests, micro -environment and socio-economic condition of the local poor. In this type of participatory forestry programme, the local people as programme beneficiaries provide their off-farm family labour. All other management inputs and technical supports are provided by the government. Here the main objectives are to integrate the people in this programme to ensure better plantation protection and to help them to find an alternative source of income to eradicate their poverty. At the same time, the local people who used to be treated as encroacher of forests and forest resources, are motivated to stop their destruction of the forest. As a result of their off farm family labour they are active beneficiaries of the programme. Generally three types of short rotation plantation are being raised under the social forestry programme viz. woodlot plantations, agroforestry plantings, and strip plantations. The Forestry Department aimed to raise the benefits from woodlots and strip planting above those of the agroforestry plots.

Int_dur: Paper discusses various changes over the past 20 years: Over the past 20 years, the region has faced several social and economical transformations. Title: Womenâ€™s participation in forest management: A cross-country analysis
Author_affil: Department of Political Science, Florida State University, 543 Bellamy, Tallahassee, FL 32306-2230, USA
Funding:
Sustainable Agriculture and Natural
Resource Management Collaborative Research Support Program
(SANREM), National Science Foundation (SES0648447) for data
collection, the Austrian Development Agency for data analysis and
reporting, the Workshop in Political Theory and Policy Analysis,
and the International Forestry Resources and Institutions
Program.
Linked_refs: Yes this study uses the same dataset as Coleman and Fleischman 2012
Stated_int: Womens' participation in forest user groups
Desired_out: Women's empowerment
Int_dur: Varies by country; paper doesn't specify
Stated_outcomes: Determinants of women's participation (IFRI household data); women's participation (IFRI aggregate data) - total number of councilors that are women, the probability that the leader of the forest association is a woman
Study_goal:
In this paper we advance the research on gender, participation,
and forestry in a number of important ways. First, we assess
participation in terms of a more complete probability model using
the theoretical insights of Agarwal (2001) by collecting data on all
of the factors she argues are associated with womenâ€™s participation.
Thus, we are able to test competing hypotheses meant to
explain participation that more fully capture the relevant
theoretical expectations. Second, while most of the previous
literature surveys communities as the unit of analysis, we use
household level survey data to compare the responsibility of
women and men within the household. Specifically, we examine
whether responsibilities for participation fall mostly upon the
wife, husband, are equally shared, or whether there is no
participation by the household at all. Third, we then extend this
analysis to examine what effects the different configurations of
participation have on institutional outcomes from the forest user
groups (FUGs). Fourth, our data analysis uses data from a
household survey administered in Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and
Uganda and thus provides an extension of the previous literature to
these countries. Fifth, and finally, we also examine the results from
an analysis of formal forest user associations in 10 countries in
order to assess broader measures of participation (including
womenâ€™s participation with forest association councils and their
leadership positions).
Study_location: Varies by country - data taken for Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico and Uganda from 2 sources: IFRI Program: 23 sites in four countries (Bolivia, Kenya, Mexico, and Uganda) identified by the International Forestry Resources and Institutions (IFRI) program in 2008; and more aggregated dataset taken from 96 forest associations in 10 countries of the IFRI program.
Study_duration: Household surveys conducted in 2008; date not indicated for IFRI aggregate data

Journal: Norsk Geografisk Tidsskrift - Norwegian Journal of Geography
Author_affil:
Department of Geography and Environmental Studies, Mekelle University, P.O. Box 231, Mekelle, Ethiopia;
Department of Geography, Ghent University, Krijgslaan 281 S8, BE 9000 Gent, Belgium
Stated_int: Land improvement of degraded hillsides, hillside plantations, reforestation
Desired_out: Land rehabilitation is seen as the most viable way of miti- gating the effects of land degradation. Accordingly, a number of projects under the poverty reduction strategy â€˜To plough from poverty to productivityâ€™ that was implemented in 2005 by the Government of Ethiopia and aided by local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and international NGOs (Haile et al. 2006), have been run as part of a long-standing struggle against soil erosion and drought in the northern highlands of Ethiopia. As a result, since the mid-1990s, forest cover has been improved by the establishment of exclosures (e.g. Asefa et al. 2003) and woodlots (Jagger & Pender 2003), as well as agroforestry, land certification for use, and integrated soil and water management (Haile et al. 2006). In addition, some land rehabilitation activities have been undertaken via food-for-work schemes.' 'In 1991, the idea of dividing the degraded and unproductive communal hillsides into smaller plots and allocating them to individuals for tree planting was initiated by local communities. Community elders and priest farmers described their ideas through the use of chronological depictions of interventions intended to provide solutions to degraded hillsides, and showed a timeline for the pro- posed activities. In this way, members of the local communities were able to express their wishes for the hills to become productive once again and hence transform their livelihoods. The demand-driven initiative was sub- sequently put into practice by local administrators and influenced both the regional land policy and the national land policy. '
Stated_outcomes: Economic benefits, determinants of hillside management
Study_goal: The authors assessed the effect of hillside plantations on the livelihoods of landless farmers in the eastern part of the Tigray Region'
Study_location: Ahrag, Dongar, Adikeshi, Kalhabile villages in the Tigray Region

Title: Impacts of Community-Based Natural Resource Management on Wealth, Food Security and Child Health in Tanzania
Author_affil: Clark University, Economics Department, Worcester, Massachusetts, United States of America
Stated_int: Community-based natural resource management (CBNRM), joint forest management (JFM), community-based forest management (CBFM), wildlife management areas (WMA)
Desired_out: In the late 1990's and early 2000's the Tanzanian government passed several pieces of legislation calling for devolution of natural resource governance to local populations through various CBNRM activities, CBFM, JFM and WMAs. Although community forest activities began as early as 1991, it was the 1998 Forest Policy and 2002 Forest Act that legally supported and facilitated community management and ownership of forests through JFM and CBFM [15,19]. Regulations for both CBFM and JFM were published in 2007; benefit-sharing arrangements were later published in 2014. The 1998 Wildlife Policy provided new opportunities for community management of wildlife resources [20]. WMA regulations were formulated in 2002 alongside the establishment of the first WMA, but a new Wildlife Policy in 2007 and â€˜Non-Consumptive Utilization of Wildlife Regulationsâ€™ in 2008 recentralized many powers and benefits to the government [21]. Revised WMA regulations in 2012 promised to return more control and benefits to communities.'
Stated_outcomes: Change in wealth status, food security, and health outcomes compared between JFM, CBFM, WMA village households (treated) and non-CBNRM households (untreated) before and after implementation
Study_goal: Here, we use a difference-in-differences estimation strategy to determine the impact of three different CBNRM approaches, Joint Forest Management (JFM), Community-based Forest Management (CBFM) and Wildlife Management Areas (WMAs), on wealth, food security and health outcomes in Tanzania. Difference-in-differences models estimate the impact of treatment by calculating the difference in change over time between a treated group and a non- treated group before and after treatment ... As such, we can determine: 1) if CBNRM in Tanzania has had an impact on participating communities' well-being and 2) to what extent the effect of CBNRM varies depending upon the type of CBNRM governance regime.'
Study_location: Tanzania

outcome.Indicators: Change in livestock numbers by household after community forestry introduction

Title:
Forests for Food Security and Livelihood
Sustainability: Policy Problems and Opportunities
for Small Farmers in Nepal
Author_affil: Faculty of Commerce, Lincoln University, Canterbury, New Zealand
Stated_int:
Community forestry in Nepal: Reforestation of community pastureland and â€œreducing and controlling livestock numbersâ€ to levels manageable with farm resources were considered to be solutions to the problem (Master Plan, 1988, p.148). The community forestry development program was implemented according to the policy guidelines (Edmonds, 2003; Hobley, 1996). In principle, community forestry transfers management responsibility to local communities, allowing them to make decisions appropriate to the community and to capture the benefits of their decisions. In practice afforestations occurred in community pasturelands. Livestock grazing and controlled forest collection were restricted
(Dhakal et al., 2005; Bhatta 2000). The government also introduced the
Forest Amendment Act in 1998 and a mandatory forest inventory introduced
to regulate forest uses and contribute to global environmental conservation,
including global climate change mitigation as directed by â€œSustainable
Forestryâ€ in Agenda 21. The policy has dictated compulsory forest inventories
and limited forest harvesting to less than 30% of mean annual increment
(MAI) for slow growing species and 60% of MAI for fast growing species1
Desired_out: Environmental protection, sustainable use of forest resources
Stated_outcomes: Change in livestock numbers by household after community forestry introduction is based on data; rest of paper is a theoretical modeling exercise
Study_goal: The purpose of this study is to...develop a model of community welfare maximization that incorporates common property resource allocation decisions and different policy constraints on forest use and household livestock holdings.
Study_location: Six CFUGs in the Dolakha, Kavre and Nuwakot districts of the mid-hill region of Nepal
Stated_mech:
Overall, livestock provide a hedge against starvation and extreme poverty, particularly for isolated mountain communities (Riethmuller, 2003).
Public forests have special importance for livestock farming and livelihoods
for mountain people in Nepal. Historically, land areas demanding
less labor for terracing and suitable for crop production were privatized.
Less productive and environmentally sensitive lands were managed as
public or communal property for production of multiple products and
services (firewood, fodder, pasture, timber, leaf litter, and other non-timber
products). As a result, almost all Nepali farmers have no private pastureland.
Instead, the farmers graze livestock in forests, or tree limbs are lopped
during seasons of animal feed deficits

Household income under current forest policy

Title:
The Link Between Community Forestry Policies
and Poverty and Unemployment in Rural Nepal
Author_affil:
Lincoln University, Commerce Division, PO Box 84, 7647 Lincoln,
Canterbury, New Zealand
Funding: Winrock-Nepal and Lincoln University, New Zealand
Linked_refs: Same data/results as Dhakal et al 2010
Stated_int:
Current government forest policy: Current government
policy dictates the use of all community forestland for
environmental conservation and limited timber production,
and provides little scope for fodder and firewood
production. Community forestry in Nepal established 13,000 forest user groups to manage community forestland.
Desired_out: Environmental conservation; sustainable forest use; empowerment of local communities
Stated_outcomes: Household income under current policy
Study_goal: The present article examines the relationship between community forest management policies on the one hand, and income and unemployment in rural areas of Nepal on the other, by modeling the effect of forest management constraints on community forest use.
Study_location: 3 districts (Dolakha, Kavre, and Nuwakot) of the mid-hill region of Nepal
Stated_mech:
However, despite the establishment
of more than 13,000 forest user groups, the impact of the
community forestry program on reducing rural poverty
and unemployment is debatable (Dhakal 2005). There
have been improvements in physical forest resources and
the environment, and flows of community development
funds from sales of forest products (Dongol et al 2002;
Gautam et al 2002; Dhakal 2005). However, parallel with
this, there has been a reduction in fodder and firewood
supplies (Malla 2000; Dhakal et al 2005), and household
income, employment, and livestock holdings have
decreased (Bhatta 2002; Timilsina 2003). Since wealthier
households have sufficient private landholdings to produce
their own fodder, the effects of these reductions
appear to have been disproportionately felt by the poorest
households, women, and minorities (Agrawal 2001;
Adhikari et al 2004; Dhakal 2006; Maskey et al 2006).

outcome.Indicators: HKM member benefitâ€“cost ratio and internal rate of return of teak growing

Title:
Community participation in a social forestry program
in Central Java, Indonesia: the effect of incentive structure
and social capital
Author_affil:
Laboratory of Agricultural History, Department
of Agricultural and Resource Economics, Graduate
School of Agricultural and Life Sciences,
The University of Tokyo, 1-1-1 Yayoi, Bunkyo-ku,
Tokyo 113-8657, Japan
Funding:
This work was supported by Japan Society for the Promotion of Science and Directorate General of Higher Education Core University Program in Applied
Biosciences.
Stated_int:
Social forestry program: A new social forestry program has been
implemented in Java to overcome encroachment of
state forests. In this program, the state and local
communities jointly manage the state forests and
share the benefits of increased forest resource stock
and flow as a result of the management. Tumpang sari (TS), a
temporal type of agroforestry, is a conventional way to
provide such incentive.In TS, a parcel of state
forestland is allocated to a farm household where
members of that household plant teak trees and
maintain the young trees for 2 years. TS attracts small
or landless farmers in need of cultivation land who are
dependent on forest resources for their livelihoods. In
exchange for labor contributed toward planting and
maintaining the trees, TS farmers receive a small cash
payment and can keep all yields from intercropping of
food crops such as maize (Zea mays indentata), peanut
(Arachis hypogaea L.), and cassava (Manihot esculenta).
After 2 years, the farmers have to leave their TS
parcel and can cultivate in a new parcel. A new social forestry program in the
Gunung Kidul District namely Hutan Kemasyarakatan
(HKM) was formulated in 2001 and established in 2002. Unlike in the conventional TS where food crop cultivation was allowed only for 2 years, in the HKM TS farmers were allowed to cultivate a parcel in state
forestland for 25 years. They would plant their parcels
with teak trees, maintain them, and share the timber
with the state. Long-term usufruct rights for farming
activities on state forestland and timber sharing are the
new arrangements introduced in the HKM.
Desired_out: To reduce encroachment in state forests
Stated_outcomes: HKM member benefitâ€“cost ratio and internal rate of return of teak growing
Study_goal:
This article aims to investigate the complete incentive structure
of the social forestry program and how the incentive
structure changes community member participation
in forest management. Property rights transfers and
economic analyses were employed to analyze the
incentive structure.This article examines the new social
forestry program implemented in state forestlands in
the Gunung Kidul District that is under the management
of the FD. It is the only state forestland under FD
management where the new social forestry program
has been implemented.
Study_location: State forestlands in the Gunung Kidul District, Java
Study_duration: Data are from field research in 2003, 2004, 2005, and 2007

Stated_int: The National Agroforestry Strategy initiated in 2004 in Tanzania promotes agroforestry technologies contributing to improve the livelihoods of resource-poor households.
Desired_out: Sustainable forest use; reforestation; improving livelihoods
Stated_outcomes: Impact of sustainable agroforestry on per capita income with respect to income percentiles
Study_goal:
The number of empirical socioeconomic papers on sustainable agroforestry practices is still small. The value added of this paper is thus to investigate
the relevance of sustainable agroforestry practices for smallholders
from an economic perspective. Three questions are addressed: (1) To what extent do households behave sustainably in terms of firewood extraction
fromtheir own agroforestry? (2)Which factors determine the likelihood
of sustainable firewood extraction? (3) Are sustainably behaving
households better off in terms of income as compared to households
practicing unsustainable agroforestry?
Study_location: Tandai, a village located in Kinole ward, Morogoro district, Tanzania
Stated_mech:
Furthermore, a World Bank Study emphasized the importance of
forest income for the rural poor (Vedeld et al., 2004). Monela et al.
(2001) reported for Tanzania that forests contribute up to 70% of the
annual household income (see also Kimaro and Lulandala, 2013;
Schaafsma et al., 2011).

Title: Assessing community-based conservation projects: A systematic review and multilevel analysis of attitudinal, behavioral, ecological, and economic outcomes
Author_affil: Anthropology Department, University of California, David, 210 Young Hall, One Shields Ave, David, CA 95616, USA
Funding: the Arnold and Mabel Beckman Foundation
Stated_int: Community-based conservation
Desired_out: A variety of approaches fall under the umbrella of CBC; each diverse in their details [3]. What unites these approaches, however, is that they typically aim to combine elements that link conservation with development, engage local communi- ties as active stakeholders, and/or devolve control over natural resources. The shared rationale is that promoting socio-economic benefits, either directly or by compen- sating the costs associated with conservation, is import- ant in both its own right, and as a key strategy for slowing deforestation and protecting endangered habi- tats and species.
Stated_outcomes: At least two of the four outcomes of interest - attitudinal, behavioral, ecological, and economic. Economic success defined as whether the community has received economic (e.g. income, direct payments) or other development benefits (e.g. roads, schools, hospitals) as a result of the project
Study_goal: The overarching question for this review is whether and to what degree CBC is effective as a strategy for solving diverse and multi-dimensional conservation problems.
Study_location: Low and middle income countries

Title: Effects of Decentralized Forest Management (DFM) on Deforestation and Poverty in Low and Middle Income Countries: A Systematic Review
Author_affil: Department of Politics, New York University, 19 West 4th Street, New York, NY 10012
Funding: 3ie
Stated_int: Decentralized forest management
Desired_out: For a program to be considered a DFM program, de jure responsibility for managing natural forest resources must pass from centralized to local authorities. This responsibility must grant local authorities the right to grant concessions or establish use restrictions. We were flexible as to the precise level of administration to which responsibilities are passed as well as whether or not the decentralization also involves granting local authorities the right to sell or transfer titles to forested lands.
Stated_outcomes: Poverty conditions of forest dwelling communities - impacts on consumption, income, or income potential
Study_goal: The first objective of this review is to assess the evidence on the effects of DFM programs on the conservation and poverty outcomes in LMICs. A second objective is to assess the extent to which these programsâ€™ effects on poverty in turn affect whether conservation benefits are realized. The third objective is to evaluate how institutional and social conditions (namely, inequality, institutional capacity, corruption, and democratic accountability) moderate the effects of DFM programs.
Study_location: Low and middle income countries

Title: Impacts of the Hutan Kamasyarakatan Social Forestry Program in the Sumberjaya Watershed, West Lampung District of Sumatra, Indonesia
Author_affil: International Food Policy Research Institute
Funding: BASIS Collaborative Research Support Program
Stated_int: Hutan Kamasyarakatan, social forestry program
Desired_out: The objective of the program is to empower local communities to practice sustainable forest management, thereby sustaining forest functions and the environment and improving social well-being. Under the program, groups of households in local communities may apply for permits for managing state forestland. To obtain a permit, a group must establish internal regulations to ensure management of the forest area according to prevailing laws; use participatory procedures for decision making, conflict resolution, and organizational management; be recognized by the community through the village administrative head; and prepare a location plan indicating the area to be managed, protection and cultivation blocks, and the period and plan for managing the area.
Stated_outcomes: Perceived change in tenure security
Study_goal: The HKm program is an innovative example of using increased tenure security as a mechanism to provide rewards for environmental services. The impacts of this approach on the sustainability of use of PF land or on poverty in Indonesia are not yet known. This study assessed those impacts, focusing on a case study of HKm implementation in the Sumberjaya watershed of the West Lampung District on the island of Sumatra.
Study_location: Sumberjaya Watershed, West Lampung District, Sumatra
